title: I have the best idea to fix Lee. EVER. Or possibly the worst....
body:
So, Lee is blind, amrite?
So how about Riot disables automatic wayfinding for him?!

So, if Lee clicks behind a wall - he doesn't run around it: *He runs against it.* (And stops)

:D

For all we know, in League's lore, there is magic that allows the brain to discern visual input, meaning you could no eyes in the first place and still see things as if you had eyes.  There's human technology in the real world that does that.  It's very Star Trekky, but it does exist, and some blind people are legally allowed to drive their cars because of it.

You're a nuisance. I'd ask you to explain to me where this technology comes from, but I honestly don't give a damn.

Have a nice day, you will not be hearing from me again.

http://edition.cnn.com/2002/HEALTH/06/13/cov.bionic.eye/

That was in 2002.

"A Canadian farmer and father of eight, Jens lost his sight 18 years ago in an accident. Now he's able to navigate through rooms, find doors and even ***drive a car to some degree***."

The procedural was illegal in the US back then, so it was done in Portugal.  The cost of producing the machine and training the individual is about 70 grand.

http://www.cbsnews.com/news/blind-man-sees-for-first-time-with-bionic-eye/

This was 2014.

"On Oct. 1, Hester became the seventh person in the U.S. to receive an implantable Argus II Retinal Prosthesis Device, also known as the bionic eye. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration approved the device in February 2013 for people with rare, degenerative eye diseases.

The device doesn't restore Hester's sight in the traditional sense, but in conjunction with specially-equipped glasses, allows him to see light, meaning he can make out contours and silhouettes of objects. Hester is now not only able to navigate a room and find a door with more ease ..."

Same Machine.  The machine is called the Argus II Retinal Prosthesis System.

Does not give true color vision, though, but because you can see the difference between light and dark, it isn't much of a stretch between this and color blind people.  And color blind people do play League of Legends; Riot wouldn't spend huge amounts of money on making a color blind system if they didn't have a significant color blind population.
